study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of emotion regulation strategies, particularly mindfulness, in reducing pain and emotional distress for women from labor to 3 months postpartum.
results_summary: Prolonged training in mindfulness-based interventions significantly decreased pain intensity during labor and increased maternal comfort 2 hours postpartum. The distraction strategy also reduced pain intensity during labor for women who practiced it prenatally.
population_specificity: Pregnant women from labor to 3 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy on patients with chronic pain.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy on chronic pain.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pain in Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dispositional mindfulness is associated with reduced pain sensitivity, comparing trial-by-trial pain assessments with overall summary ratings.
results_summary: Dispositional mindfulness was linked to reduced pain on the McGill Pain Questionnaire's sensory and affective dimensions but showed no significant association with experimental thermal pain assessments like threshold, tolerance, or skin conductance response.
population_specificity: 131 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29.09 years, 55.7% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate neural activation changes in corticolimbic regions during implicit emotion regulation in depressed patients after a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI).
results_summary: The study found decreased activation in the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC) in response to angry faces after MBI, correlating with improved decentering, reduced brooding, and decreased depressive symptoms. The PER group showed decreased amygdala activation in response to happy faces, while the MBI group showed no significant change in this region.
population_specificity: Depressed patients with a recurrent lifetime history.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a mindfulness training program (MMWR) in reducing substance use and relapse outcomes among ethnoculturally diverse women in residential treatment for substance use disorder.
results_summary: MMWR showed protective effects against marijuana use, delaying time to first use and reducing days of use, with mindfulness practice time predicting better outcomes. It also correlated with reduced alcohol intoxication and improved mindfulness skills, but no effects were observed for other substances.
population_specificity: Ethnoculturally diverse women (60% Hispanic/Latina, 18% non-Hispanic Black) in residential treatment for substance use disorder.
study_duration: 6-week intervention period with 7 months of follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on resilience-promoting practices for nursing students, including mindfulness, to reduce burnout and improve retention.
results_summary: The study identified mindfulness as one of several educational strategies to enhance resilience in nursing students, alongside reflection, positive reframing, and problem-based learning. It highlighted promising evidence for these interventions but noted that resilience-focused interventions are not yet well-developed.
population_specificity: Prelicensure nursing students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the MYmind Mindfulness-based program in improving ADHD symptoms, executive functions, and family functioning in children with ADHD and their parents.
results_summary: Parents reported reduced parenting stress and improved parenting styles post-intervention. Six months later, significant improvements were noted in children's inattention, executive functions, learning problems, aggression, and peer relations, with overreactivity decreasing consistently.
population_specificity: 30 children aged 9-14 years with an ADHD diagnosis and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based and ACT-based interventions in improving mental well-being and mindfulness among parents of children with developmental disabilities.
results_summary: The interventions were effective in reducing parental stress, anxiety, and depression, but their impact on increasing mindfulness was inconclusive.
population_specificity: Parents of children with developmental disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Therapy for Insomnia (MBTI) with a Sleep Hygiene, Education, and Exercise Program (SHEEP) in improving sleep outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: MBTI showed significant improvements in subjective and objective sleep quality, with sustained benefits at 6-month follow-up, while SHEEP only improved subjective sleep quality. MBTI also demonstrated greater reductions in insomnia severity and sleep medication use compared to SHEEP.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 50-80 with poor sleep quality (PSQI score ≥5).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but assessments were done post-intervention and at 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindful parenting interventions on parenting mindfulness and parenting behaviors, with secondary outcomes including parenting stress, psychological wellbeing, relationships, and child behavioral outcomes.
results_summary: Mindful parenting interventions showed a moderate effect on parenting mindfulness scores for parents of typically developing children but no significant effect on overall parenting stress. Findings on other outcomes were inconclusive due to insufficient data.
population_specificity: Parents with children or youths aged 24 years and below, including clinical and non-clinical samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multicomponent rehabilitation program combining mindfulness-based and acceptance-based therapy with physical activity counseling was more effective than treatment as usual for patients with recently diagnosed fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The multicomponent program showed no significant improvement over treatment as usual in primary or secondary outcomes, except for slight improvements in mindfulness tendency and perceived benefits of exercise. No statistically significant differences were found in pain, fatigue, sleep quality, or other disease-related measures.
population_specificity: Patients aged 20-50 with recently diagnosed fibromyalgia, engaged in work or studies within the past 2 years.
effective_dosage: 10-session mindfulness-based group program followed by 12 weeks of physical activity counseling.
study_duration: 12-month follow-up (intervention duration not explicitly stated beyond sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a school-based mindfulness program on children's Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQoL) compared to relaxation and inactive control groups, while examining moderating effects of gender, grade, and independent practice.
results_summary: The mindfulness group showed significant improvement in HRQoL after 9 weeks and at 26 weeks compared to the active control group. Girls, 7th and 8th graders, and those with regular independent mindfulness practice benefited the most.
population_specificity: 3,519 Finnish students aged 12-15 from 56 schools (50% boys, 50% girls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on improving resilience in vulnerable women, specifically female sex workers and addicted women.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR significantly increased resilience scores in the intervention group compared to the control group, while resilience scores in the control group decreased over time. The post-test resilience score in the intervention group was significantly higher than in the control group.
population_specificity: Female sex workers and addicted women in Kerman, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of mindfulness practices in improving health outcomes during pregnancy and the postpartum period.
results_summary: The study found sufficient evidence that mindfulness practices reduce anxiety, depression, and stress during pregnancy, with potential benefits extending into the postpartum period. Limited evidence was found for other aspects of pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant and postpartum women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate mindfulness-based therapy as a non-pharmacological treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder in emergency responders.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based therapy was among the therapeutic options that presented positive results, aligning with national and international treatment recommendations. The study did not provide specific details on the magnitude of mindfulness's effects compared to other therapies.
population_specificity: Emergency responders with post-traumatic stress disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore evidence-based mental health interventions, including mindfulness, for adolescents and young adults living with or affected by HIV to inform future mental health programs.
results_summary: The study identified group-based mindfulness as one of the psychosocial interventions used, with 11 out of 13 studies reporting positive effects on mental health outcomes, though specific efficacy data for mindfulness alone was not detailed.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (ages 10-24) living with HIV (AYALH) or affected by HIV in their families (AYAAH), primarily in sub-Saharan Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of benefit from MBCT for psychological distress in breast cancer patients and determine the optimal number of sessions for clinical effect.
results_summary: Better program adherence (attendance) significantly predicted remission and response, with the seventh session marking the point where remission rates exceeded 50%. Sociodemographic and clinical characteristics did not influence outcomes.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (N = 74)
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to cover eight sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on the psychological impact of COVID-19 on healthcare professionals and assess the effectiveness of interventions like mindfulness in managing stress.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness, along with other psychological interventions, improved resilience, self-efficacy, and sleep quality while reducing anxiety and depression in healthcare professionals. These interventions were deemed crucial for managing acute stress responses.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two mindfulness-based interventions (mindfulness of breath and mindfulness of pain) versus cognitive-behavioral pain psychoeducation in reducing preoperative and postoperative pain and opioid use in TJA patients.
results_summary: Mindfulness of breath (MoB) was most effective in reducing preoperative pain, while mindfulness of pain (MoP) resulted in the least postoperative pain intensity and interference. Both MoB and MoP reduced postoperative opioid use compared to cognitive-behavioral intervention.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total joint arthroplasty (TJA) of the knee or hip (N = 118, mean age = 65, 73 female, 110 Caucasian).
effective_dosage: Single 20-minute session delivered during a 2-hour preoperative education program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reminder e-mails could enhance yoga therapy adherence and improve fatigue, depression, and quality of life in cancer patients, while also examining long-term effects of yoga.
results_summary: Reminder e-mails significantly improved yoga practice frequency and reduced general and emotional fatigue, with practice frequency partially mediating emotional fatigue reduction. Long-term yoga therapy benefits were observed for fatigue, depression, and quality of life, though physical and cognitive fatigue improvements were not linked to practice frequency.
population_specificity: Cancer patients who completed an 8-week yoga therapy program.
effective_dosage: Weekly reminder e-mails for 24 weeks post-therapy.
study_duration: 8-week yoga therapy followed by 24-week reminder phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how upstream approaches, including mindfulness, enhance resilience and reduce allostatic load to facilitate flourishing from an early age.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, as part of broader community projects, contributes to protective and buffering factors that enhance resilience and reduce allostatic load, potentially influencing core behaviors through better relationships with self, community, and the environment.
population_specificity: Early life individuals and communities (broad, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in improving psychological wellbeing and quality of life in men with prostate cancer.
results_summary: MBIs showed small to moderate effects for psychological outcomes, moderate effects for quality of life, and large effects for post-traumatic growth, though the evidence was limited by methodological weaknesses.
population_specificity: Men with prostate cancer

study_goal: To systematically review and meta-analyze the effects of Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBIs) on ADHD symptoms, associated features, neurocognitive impairments, mindfulness skills, and quality of life in both adults and children.
results_summary: MBIs were more effective than waiting lists in improving ADHD symptoms and other outcomes in both adults and children, with medium effect sizes in adults. However, active-controlled studies showed low/negligible effects, and no active-controlled studies were conducted in children.
population_specificity: Adults and children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBIs) with control groups focusing on dietary or exercise-based behavioral changes in individuals with overweight/obesity and/or binge eating disorder (BED).
results_summary: MBIs were more effective than controls in increasing mindfulness scores and reducing BED symptoms but showed no significant advantage in reducing body mass. Longer interventions improved mindfulness and BED symptoms more, while shorter interventions showed greater reductions in body mass.
population_specificity: Individuals with overweight/obesity and/or binge eating disorder (BED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Therapeutic Riding (THR) and HeartMath (HM) mindfulness-based interventions in reducing stress in adolescents with autism spectrum disorder.
results_summary: Both HM and THR reduced cortisol levels immediately after sessions, with HM showing greater impact on heart-rate variability. THR had more effect on decreasing some self-reported stressors, but neither intervention significantly affected follow-up cortisol levels within a week.
population_specificity: Adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (ages 12-21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement (MORE) as an adjunct treatment to methadone maintenance therapy (MMT) for reducing illicit opioid use and chronic pain.
results_summary: Participants receiving MORE showed significantly fewer days of illicit drug use, lower craving, reduced pain, and improved well-being compared to those receiving only MMT. The benefits persisted through the 16-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Individuals in methadone maintenance treatment (MMT) for opioid use disorder with chronic pain.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly two-hour MORE group sessions.
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) and Behavioral Activation Therapy for Anhedonia (BATA) on anhedonia symptoms and resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) in a transdiagnostic, anhedonic sample.
results_summary: MBCT showed significant reductions in anhedonia symptoms and rsFC within the default mode network (DMN) and frontoparietal network (FPN), with no difference in efficacy compared to BATA. Changes in rsFC were unrelated to symptom improvements at the individual level, but higher FPN rsFC correlated with lower anhedonia across timepoints.
population_specificity: Medication-free, transdiagnostic, anhedonic adults.
effective_dosage: Up to 15 therapy sessions (specific mindfulness dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration covered pre-, during, and post-treatment MRI scans (exact timeline not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand first-year university students' experiences and perceptions of using the My Viva Plan (MVP) web-based application to support healthy living.
results_summary: Participants reported varied use of MVP, influenced by emotions, situations, and thinking, which acted as facilitators or barriers. The study suggested the Behaviors, Emotions, Situations, Thinking framework could help dietitians optimize ehealth tool support for lifestyle behavior change.
population_specificity: First-year university students from the University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada (n = 32).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of non-drug interventions, including mindfulness meditation, for preventing or treating anxiety in people with aphasia post-stroke.
results_summary: The study found no definitive evidence of benefit from mindfulness meditation for anxiety outcomes in people with aphasia post-stroke, though it was identified as a potentially promising intervention alongside other non-drug approaches. The quality of evidence supporting mindfulness was limited, with higher-quality studies showing no significant effects.
population_specificity: People with aphasia post-stroke (≥25% of study participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions for improving individual and dyadic outcomes in couples and other dyads.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions for couples were found to increase mindfulness, self-compassion, well-being, and quality of life, with initial evidence of benefits for psychopathological symptoms and stress measures. Relationship quality was the predominant dyadic outcome, suggesting mindfulness training can enhance perceived relationship quality.
population_specificity: Couples and other dyads in clinical and nonclinical settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 7-week meditation and mindfulness program, combined with standard supportive care, could reduce perceived stress more effectively than standard supportive care alone in women with recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL).
results_summary: The study found that perceived stress decreased significantly in both the intervention and control groups after 7 weeks, with a larger reduction in the intervention group. At the 12-month follow-up, stress levels remained significantly lower than baseline in both groups.
population_specificity: Women with recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL).
effective_dosage: 7-week daily at-home meditation and mindfulness program combined with group sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) to pharmacological treatment as usual (TAU) improves clinical outcomes, such as headache frequency and medication intake, in patients with high-frequency episodic migraine without aura (HFEM).
results_summary: Patients receiving TAU + ACT showed statistically significant reductions in headache frequency and medication intake by month 3, with a mean reduction of 3.3 headache days, compared to an increase of 0.7 days in the TAU-only group. The combined treatment also demonstrated earlier and more sustained improvements in secondary measures like disability, headache impact, and psychological factors.
population_specificity: Patients with high-frequency episodic migraine without aura (HFEM), experiencing 9-14 headache days per month.
effective_dosage: Six 90-minute weekly group sessions of ACT therapy and two supplementary "booster" sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the efficacy of mindfulness meditation in treating military-related PTSD by synthesizing evidence from randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation significantly alleviated military-related PTSD symptoms compared to control conditions, with consistent effectiveness across different intervention formats, durations, and control types. The standardized mean difference was -0.33 (95% CI [-0.45, -0.21], p < 0.0001).
population_specificity: Military personnel with PTSD.
study_duration: Varied (short-term or standard duration, exact lengths not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively examine the effects of stress management interventions, including mindfulness, on reducing stress, depression, and anxiety among socioeconomically disadvantaged parents, and to explore moderators of these effects.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions showed a small but significant effect in reducing depression (g = -0.16) compared to other interventions, with short-term benefits for stress and depression but limited long-term effects. The study also found that interventions lasting 1-3 months had greater stress-reducing effects than longer durations.
population_specificity: Socioeconomically disadvantaged parents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the impact of migraine on various life domains and compare the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction versus headache education.
results_summary: The study found that migraine negatively impacts overall life, emotional health, cognitive function, and specific domains like work, family, and social life. Participants reported isolation, frustration, guilt, fear, avoidance behavior, and stigma due to migraine.
population_specificity: Adults with migraine (n = 81) from two randomized clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention (MBRP) in reducing or stopping cannabis use among volunteer users.
results_summary: Preliminary results showed no significant difference in cannabis use between the MBRP and treatment-as-usual groups at week 8, but qualitative changes in consumption patterns were reported by MBRP participants. The study suggests mindfulness may still hold promise in treating substance use disorders.
population_specificity: Twenty volunteer cannabis users willing to reduce or stop consumption.
effective_dosage: Eight-week outpatient MBRP program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if baseline heart rate variability (HRV) changes could predict improvement in emotional interference after mindfulness-based intervention (BMT) compared to fluoxetine (FLX) and a quality-of-life (QoL) control group in patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).
results_summary: The study found that baseline HRV flexibility predicted improvement in emotional interference only in the FLX group, not in the BMT group. This suggests that HRV may not be a predictive marker for mindfulness-based intervention efficacy in GAD patients.
population_specificity: Adult patients diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based online training program versus a cognitive-behavioral one in reducing work-related perseverative thinking (PT) and examine their underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study expects both interventions to reduce work-related PT compared to a waitlist control, with mindfulness-based training improving mindfulness facets as the primary mechanism for lower PT levels. The study will analyze processes at multiple levels (daily, weekly, across weeks, and between individuals).
population_specificity: Employees working at least part-time during regular work hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the relationship between mindfulness and emotional intelligence among healthcare professionals and students.
results_summary: The study found a positive relationship between mindfulness and emotional intelligence, particularly in emotion regulation, and a negative relationship with emotional exhaustion. Mindfulness training interventions were effective in promoting emotional balance, awareness, acceptance, and reducing exhaustion.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals and students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the relative efficacies of cognitive therapy (CT), mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), behavior therapy (BT), and treatment as usual (TAU) in improving pain, physical function, mood, and sleep disturbance in people with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that CT, MBSR, and BT produced similar pretreatment to posttreatment improvements in all outcomes, with comparable maintenance of gains at 6-month follow-up. All three active treatments outperformed TAU, with significant differences emerging by session 6.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain (N = 521).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether EEG measures from a consumer-grade headband could serve as correlates of state mindfulness during focused attention meditation.
results_summary: Device measures detected attention lapses within participants and showed significant associations with self-reported trait mindfulness, attentional control, nonattachment, and decentering, explaining approximately 30% of variance in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Adult participants (N=68, mean age not specified).

study_goal: The researchers explored the potential of psychedelic substances like psilocybin to promote positive lifestyle changes, including mindfulness practices, for improved health and well-being.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that psilocybin may facilitate favourable behavioural changes in conditions marked by rigid patterns, such as depression and anxiety, but does not specifically report results on mindfulness.
population_specificity: Patients with depression, anxiety, substance misuse, and other rigid behavioural patterns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) could reduce depressive symptoms in perimenopausal women and examine baseline characteristics as moderators of treatment effects.
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced depressive symptoms, perceived stress, and anxiety while increasing resilience and improving sleep. Women with a history of major depression, recent stressful life events, early menopause transition, or emotional sensitivity to hormone fluctuations showed greater mood benefits from MBSR.
population_specificity: 104 healthy perimenopausal women from the community.
effective_dosage: 8-week group intervention involving meditation and yoga (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential and limitations of mindfulness strategies in treating obesity, particularly in improving dysfunctional eating behaviors and weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness, when combined with other psychological therapies, diet, and physical activity, improves weight loss, food awareness, self-acceptance, and reduces food cravings and emotional eating. However, long-term effectiveness and clinical integration require further research.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy in reducing obsessive-compulsive symptoms in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that mindfulness-based cognitive therapy had a moderate but statistically significant effect in reducing obsessive-compulsive symptoms compared to control groups (standardized mean difference: 0.283, p = .002). It was concluded to be an effective approach for individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions on quality of life and menopausal symptoms in women.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions significantly improved total quality of life and vasomotor and physical quality of life in menopausal women, but there was insufficient data to assess effects on psychological and sexual subscales or vasomotor symptoms. Heterogeneity remained after sensitivity analyses.
population_specificity: Menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a mindfulness-based stress reduction program on reducing fetal growth restriction (FGR) and improving perinatal outcomes in high-risk pregnancies.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized trial comparing mindfulness-based stress reduction, Mediterranean diet, and usual care, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The study is designed to assess perinatal outcomes, neurodevelopment, and cardiovascular health in children up to 2 years of age.
population_specificity: High-risk singleton pregnancies (N=1218) at 19.0-23.6 weeks' gestation, identified using criteria from the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.
study_duration: Intervention administered from enrollment (19.0-23.6 weeks' gestation) to 34.0-36.6 weeks' gestation.

study_goal: The researchers sought to review the benefits of meditation on alleviating loneliness.
results_summary: Eleven of thirteen studies reported improvements in loneliness, while two had unclear or indirect findings. The analysis highlighted positive results, small randomized trials, and a lack of diverse demographic data.
population_specificity: Studies included various populations across 10 countries, but demographic specifics were lacking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a family mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) in improving child self-control, ADHD symptoms, and parental mental health when added to care-as-usual (CAU) for children with ADHD.
results_summary: Family MBI+CAU showed a small, non-significant improvement in child self-control deficits but significantly more children reliably improved compared to CAU-only. Parent outcomes, including ADHD symptoms, well-being, and mindful parenting, showed larger and more durable improvements.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-16 years with remaining ADHD symptoms after CAU and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emotion (dys)regulation in gambling disorder (GD) and its association with mindfulness abilities.
results_summary: The study found that GD is associated with deficits in emotion regulation, including emotional suppression, which is linked to reduced mindfulness abilities. It supports the need for tailored interventions addressing these deficits in GD.
population_specificity: Individuals with gambling disorder (GD), comprising 5,242 participants across 38 studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions, including mindfulness-meditation-relaxation, in promoting resilience among physicians.
results_summary: Mindfulness-meditation-relaxation interventions showed small but significant benefits (Hedges's g = 0.208) for resilience in physicians, though emotional-supportive-coping interventions had slightly higher effects. Longer interventions (>1 week) demonstrated greater efficacy.
population_specificity: Physicians (n = 580)
study_duration: Varied (some up to a week, others >1 week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a remote, group-mediated physical activity intervention based on social cognitive theory and mindfulness-based relapse prevention on self-efficacy, satisfaction with functioning, and HRQOL in obese older adults with chronic pain.
results_summary: The intervention led to moderate improvements in self-efficacy for walking and large improvements in satisfaction with physical functioning, as well as positive effects on pain and physical functioning subscales of the SF-36.
population_specificity: Obese older adults (mean age 70.21 ± 5.22 years) with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) could improve coping skills and reduce negative emotional effects in individuals newly diagnosed with relapsing MS (RMS).
results_summary: The MBI group showed significant improvements in coping skills (COPE measure) and depression (HADS-D subscale) post-intervention, as well as reduced perceived stress, but no significant changes in anxiety or long-term outcomes at six months.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed (within one year) individuals with relapsing MS (RMS), predominantly women (81%), mean age 37.1 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of an 8-week mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP) program in reducing hypnotic use and insomnia severity among women with chronic insomnia.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in hypnotic use immediately post-intervention and at 2-month follow-up, as well as greater reductions in insomnia severity at 4- and 6-month follow-ups compared to the control group. However, baseline differences in hypnotic use between groups may have influenced the results.
population_specificity: Women with chronic insomnia and hypnotic use.
effective_dosage: 8-week group-delivered MBRP program (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 8 weeks (intervention), with follow-ups up to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation training for young people whose parents were affected by HIV.
results_summary: The study found mindfulness meditation training to be an effective approach for improving mental health in adolescents with HIV-affected parents. However, only one intervention study was identified, limiting broader conclusions.
population_specificity: Adolescents in Myanmar whose parents were affected by HIV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psychological interventions like mindfulness-based cognitive therapy during antidepressant tapering could effectively prevent depression relapse compared to long-term antidepressant use alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in time to depressive relapse between psychological interventions during antidepressant tapering and antidepressant monotherapy. Younger age at onset, shorter remission duration, and higher residual depressive symptoms were associated with higher relapse risk, but no moderators influenced the effectiveness of psychological interventions.
population_specificity: Adults in full or partial remission from depression (mean age 49.2 years, 73.1% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy and potential mechanisms of a mindful living with challenge (MLWC) intervention in alleviating psychological problems (e.g., PTSD, depression, anxiety) among COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to assess differences in mental health and physical symptoms between the MLWC intervention group and a waitlist control group, with results expected to demonstrate improved psychological well-being and quality of life.
population_specificity: COVID-19 survivors from Hubei Province, China (over 1,600 participants).
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up at post-program and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a consumer-based mobile meditation app on wellness, specifically perceived stress, depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbance, in outpatient obstetric and gynecology patients during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that using the meditation app significantly reduced perceived stress, depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbance at days 14 and 30 compared to standard care, with high user satisfaction reported.
population_specificity: Outpatient obstetric and gynecology patients during the COVID-19 pandemic.
effective_dosage: Not specified (prescribed mobile meditation app for 30 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effects on depressive symptoms of a culturally adapted version of the UPLIFT mindfulness-based program for Hispanic adults with epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found that UPLIFT was feasible and acceptable, with high recruitment and retention rates. It significantly reduced depressive symptoms compared to usual care, particularly at 6 months, though effects slightly diminished by 12 months.
population_specificity: Hispanic adults with epilepsy and elevated depressive symptoms (n = 72, mean age 43.3, 71% female, 67% primary Spanish speakers).
effective_dosage: Eight weekly telephone sessions (median adherence: six sessions).
study_duration: 8 weeks (with follow-up assessments at 6 and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a mindfulness-based programme (MBP) for reducing stress in university students, its action mechanisms, and whether virtual reality (VR) exposure could enhance adherence.
results_summary: Both MBP and MBP + VR were superior to relaxation in reducing stress and improving secondary outcomes, with medium-to-large effects posttreatment and at follow-up. The long-term effects were mediated by mindfulness and self-compassion, and VR exposure improved treatment adherence.
population_specificity: 280 university students from two Spanish universities.
study_duration: Posttreatment and 6-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the active ingredients and neurobiological mechanisms of compassion meditation (CM) by comparing its effects to a placebo and a familiarity-control condition.
results_summary: CM increased brain responses to suffering others in the medial orbitofrontal cortex (mOFC), correlating with increased compassion-related feelings. These effects were not fully explained by familiarity or placebo effects.
population_specificity: 57 participants in a randomized trial.
effective_dosage: 4-week CM program delivered via smartphone application (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yoga (which includes mindfulness) or cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) improved autonomic dysfunction (HR and HRV) and whether baseline autonomic function predicted pain outcomes in Veterans with Gulf War illness (GWI).
results_summary: Veterans who received CBT showed a tendency toward higher mean HR post-treatment, while baseline autonomic function (lower HR, higher HRV) predicted greater pain reduction across both treatments. Better baseline autonomic function predicted greater pain reduction with yoga, whereas worse baseline function predicted better outcomes with CBT.
population_specificity: Veterans with Gulf War illness (GWI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a molybdenum-based polyoxometalate nanocluster (POM) combined with GelMA hydrogel could scavenge ROS and promote osteogenesis in diabetic bone defects.
results_summary: The GelMA/POM hydrogel effectively reduced oxidative stress, promoted osteoblast proliferation, and enhanced osteogenic differentiation by activating the PI3K/Akt pathway, leading to improved bone regeneration in diabetic mice.
population_specificity: Diabetic mice with bone defects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a molybdenum-based nanoreactor (HMMo-SAzyme) and evaluate its in vivo antibacterial activity by enhancing catalytic conversion of H2O2 to •OH under physiological conditions.
results_summary: The nanoreactor demonstrated excellent antibacterial activity in vitro and in vivo, with negligible biological toxicity. The cascade catalytic system effectively generated •OH in an acid-enhanced environment, leading to bacterial elimination.
population_specificity: Bacterial infection models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic efficiency of molybdenum target X-ray and high-frequency color Doppler flow imaging (CDFI) in the early diagnosis of breast carcinoma.
results_summary: CDFI showed higher positive detection rates, sensitivity, and accuracy than molybdenum target X-ray alone, but combining both methods further improved diagnostic accuracy. CDFI detected more masses and lymph node metastases, while molybdenum target X-ray identified more microcalcifications.
population_specificity: 102 patients with suspected early-stage breast carcinoma admitted to Henan Provincial People's Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of molybdenum nanodots (MNDs) for treating acute lung injury (ALI) by assessing their ability to scavenge reactive oxygen species (ROS) and mitigate inflammation.
results_summary: MNDs significantly reduced lung oxidative stress, inflammation, protein permeability, and histological severity in ALI mice, likely by inhibiting the NLRP3-dependent pyroptotic pathway, without causing safety issues.
population_specificity: ALI mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of molybdenum (Mo) application on the morphological and physiological characteristics of soybean intercropped with maize.
results_summary: The study found that Mo application at 120 g ha-1 significantly improved soybean growth, yield attributes, and nutrient uptake efficiency in maize-soybean intercropping systems, with notable increases in leaf area index, total plant biomass, transpiration rate, stomatal conductance, and grain yield.
population_specificity: Soybean plants intercropped with maize in a field setting.
effective_dosage: 0, 60, 120, and 180 g ha-1 of sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel biomaterial composite scaffold containing molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) for bone regeneration, addressing limitations of current bone grafting techniques.
results_summary: The PLGA-MBG-MoS2-Sim composite scaffold demonstrated enhanced protein adsorption, water retention, biodegradation (54% after 28 days), and in vitro bioactivity, promoting hydroxyapatite formation. In vivo studies showed higher bone regeneration rates, and the scaffold was biocompatible with C3H10T1/2 cells, exhibiting increased alkaline phosphatase and mineralization activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models, including C3H10T1/2 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel magnetic adsorbent (PB/Fe3O4/MoS2) for removing cesium (Cs+) from radioactive wastewater.
results_summary: The PB/Fe3O4/MoS2 nanocomposite demonstrated high adsorption capacity (80.51 mg/g) for Cs+, reaching 90% equilibrium adsorption in under 110 minutes, with good performance across a pH range of 2-7. The adsorption followed Langmuir isothermal and second-order kinetic models, indicating chemical adsorption and endothermic reactions.
population_specificity: Radioactive wastewater treatment (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adsorbent material, not a consumable dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (adsorption experiments conducted over short timeframes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of molybdenum (Mo) powder in enhancing the degradation of sulfamethoxazole (SMX) in a sodium percarbonate (SPC) system, focusing on oxidant consumption, pH range, and catalyst reusability.
results_summary: The Mo/STPP-Fe(Ⅲ)/SPC system demonstrated high efficiency in degrading SMX, achieving near-complete degradation in 60 minutes with a higher removal rate (0.1367 min-1) compared to systems without Mo or STPP. The system was cost-effective, requiring only 0.2 mM SPC, and exhibited excellent stability and reusability of Mo.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental study, not human subjects).
